urn:contentItem:65RC-PB71-DYG0-90WH-00000-00VIC:NSW man charged with stealing Vic firewood2022-06-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:NSW man charged with stealing Vic firewoodMELBOURNE June 20

  A NSW man potentially faces a year in jail and fine of nearly $10,000 after he was busted allegedly collecting firewood in Victoria.


   The unnamed man was charged by Conservation Regulator Authorised Officers with 12 offences, including illegal firewood collecting and habitat destruction, after being observed at Lake Moodemere near Rutherglen, in the state?s northeast last year.
   In Victoria, it is a crime to remove or destroy vegetation on public land without proper authorisation.
   A joint operation between the Conservation Regulator, Forest Fire Management Victoria and Parks Victoria led officers to the man in May last year.
   He is due to appear in Wodonga Magistrates Court on July 5.
   ?The illegal removal of native vegetation is devastating for biodiversity,? Hume Conservation Regulator regional manager Greg Chant said.
   ?Habitat loss has a serious impact on iconic native species that rely on our forests to survive, such as the Powerful Owl, South-eastern Red-tailed Black Cockatoo, Greater Glider, and many others.?

urn:contentItem:67SB-0SP1-JBR4-F2W0-00000-00Timber crews ignored by Victorian government2023-03-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisTimber crews ignored by Victorian government

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Peter Hunt

Victorian Government bureaucrats are handing out contracts worth between $100,000 and $461,200 to civil construction companies to clear strategic fuel breaks, rather than using out-of-work VicForests harvest & haulage contractors.

25 of VicForests' 27 harvest and haulage crews are already receiving stand-down payments from VicForests, worth anywhere from 67 per cent to 90 per cent of their contracted amount, after last November's Supreme Court ruling locked them out of the state's native forests.

But rather than using those crews to build strategic fire breaks, the Department of Environment, Energy and Climate Action is awarding limited taxpayer funds to civil construction companies.

The Buying Victoria website shows DEECA (previously DELWP) has awarded 14 contracts, worth a total $2.5 million, to mainly civil construction companies, to build strategic fire breaks in forests and along roads, from Gippsland to the Upper Murray River catchment.

Just last month DEECA released another request for tender (T2023-0006) to clear 20m-wide fire breaks on either side of 8.1km of road in forests north of Woodside in Gippsland.

Australian Forest Contractors Association general manager Carlie Porteous said the lobby group had "raised concerns with the Victorian Labor Government as early as February 2021 regarding the use of non-forestry contractors completing land based activities".

"We have been made aware on numerous occasions that, not only are experienced forestry contractors overlooked, but Victorians themselves. In some instances work is being awarded to contracting businesses in other states."

But a Government spokesman rejected the claim, stating "numerous forest contractors have been engaged to deliver strategic fuel breaks, including those that also undertake work for VicForests" and "forest contractors are actively engaged across DEECA's land and fire management programs".

Yet the Buying Victoria website shows contracts are not being awarded to VicForests crews, who are reporting that without work they are losing highly skilled crews to other industries.

Oddly, Forest Fire Management Victoria, which sits within DEECA, is desperate to retain the skills and machinery of harvest and haulage contractors, who have been called on to help fight every major fire, build emergency fuel breaks and clear roads of fallen timber and dangerous standing trees.

Orbost forestry consultant Garry Squires said the government was way behind in delivering strategic fuel breaks and should be using out-of-work harvest and haulage crews to get back on track.

"Basically you have contractors on 70 to 90 per cent of what they would have earned, sitting at home," Mr Squires said. "The government should say 'how about we take you all up to 100 per cent to catch up on our strategic fire breaks?'."

One government insider said the relationship between DEECA and VicForests was "so toxic" no agreement to engage harvest and haulage contractors to build breaks would go anywhere.

urn:contentItem:6344-1PT1-JD34-V388-00000-00Prescribed burn for Little Desert park2021-07-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Prescribed burn for Little Desert parkAlison Foletta

Forest Fire Management Victoria advised that the following planned burn will be carried out at Little Desert NP - Jungkum Track.

This planned burn will run for until Thursday, July 15.

The objective of this burns is to provide bushfire protection by reducing overall fuel hazard and bushfire hazard in the landscape.

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in areas close to or in burn areas may be restricted.

Smoke may be visible from the Little Desert National Park during the planned burn period.

If you are experiencing any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure, the Department of Health and Human Services advises that you should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024

The department advised those in the vicinity to close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering.

Road travel may be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke.

Signs may be in place to slow traffic. Forest Fire Management advised people to obey all traffic signs and instructions from fire agency crews near the burn.

THE STATE is spending $517 million on bushfire preparation with another 600 seasonal firefighters now ready, plus 154 new Forest Fire Management Victoria recruits. Fire management crews have already completed 470 burns since July to reduce fuel loads, including recent "precision burning" close to where people live.They will protect homes, catchments, power supplies, schools, hospitals and key transport routes, FFMVic's chief fire officer Chris Hardman said.

urn:contentItem:656R-XST1-JD34-V2V9-00000-00Penalties apply for fires left burning2022-04-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Penalties apply for fires left burningBeau Greenway

On-the-spot fines of more than $500 will be handed out to anyone in breach of Victoria's campfire rules this Easter.

Campfires must contained in purpose-built fireplaces, trenches at least 30 centimetres deep or be surrounded by rocks or other non-flammable materials, while branches and logs are to be less than one metre long.

Acting manager of regulatory operations Andrew Dean said Conservation Regulator and Forest Fire Management officers would patrol the state and could issue fines of $545.

"An unattended campfire can become a bushfire in a matter of minutes. Even in the cooler autumn climate, embers can spark and start a fire that spreads quickly in the bush, putting people and the environment at risk," Mr Dean said.

"Campfires must never be left unattended and need to be extinguished with water, not soil, as fires can smoulder under soil. If a fire is cool to touch, it is safe to leave."

A maximum penalty of up to $18,174 may apply.

urn:contentItem:63Y4-PW51-F0J6-J4C4-00000-00Planned burning2021-10-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Planned burningChris McLennan

A drone has successfully ignited a planned burn in the Grampians.

The drone dropped aerial incendiaries into thick bush where parks rangers find it difficult to reach for the pre-summer ecological burns.

The trial saw Forest Fire Management Victoria crews in the Wimmera working with a licensed operator to pilot the drone.

The drone was found to increase accuracy and save crews time from navigating the difficult terrain on foot.

urn:contentItem:64YT-X471-JD3N-519F-00000-00Firewood season begins2022-03-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 12Firewood season begins

FOREST Fire Management Victoria has opened the firewood collection season across the Barwon South West region.

The autumn firewood collection season, from March to the end of June, allows members of the public to take firewood from designated forest areas for personal use.

Collection limits include a maximum of two cubic metres per person per day and a maximum of 16 cubic metres per household per financial year.

Felling trees and cutting downed hollow logs remains prohibited. The Conservation Regulator, FFMVic and Parks Victoria will conduct random and targeted patrols in the forest areas, issuing fines to those committing firewood offences, with an option to take some offenders to court.

FFMVic deputy chief fire officer Andrew Morrow said limitations were important for a number of reasons, including protecting the cultural and environmental significance of sites. An interactive map showing designated collection areas is available at ffm.vic.gov.au/firewood

urn:contentItem:63XP-SH51-F0J6-J0D5-00000-00Crews set to slash2021-10-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Crews set to slashChris Pedler

Forest Fire Management Victoria crews have started slashing in the Greater Bendigo region to reduce the risk of grassfires ahead of summer. Higher-than-average rainfall during spring has resulted in delays to slashing and seen an increase in grass growth. Mechanical fuel management works such as clearing, mowing, mulching and slashing are part of FFM Victoria's year-round fuel reduction program aimed at reducing bushfire-risk in communities.

urn:contentItem:62G0-GY21-F0J6-J23N-00000-00Traditional burn planned near Huntly2021-04-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisTraditional burn planned near Huntly

A TRADITIONAL Owner burn has been planned for the Whipstick area on Sunday.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the Country Fire Authority have advised the 20-hectare burn will take place at Djandak Wi - Brights Lane, about six kilometres west of Huntly.

The burn will start at 10am on Sunday and last through to 8pm on Monday, if weather permits.

Read other news: 2021 Bendigo White Night confirmed for October by state government

Authorities warned residents that smoke from the burn could be visible until April 24.

Residents in Whipstick, Eaglehawk North, Huntly North, Huntly, Eaglehawk, Woodvale, and Neilborough could be affected.

Forest Fire Management Victoria staff will be patrolling the burn until it is declared safe.

For more information about the burn, visit plannedburns.ffm.vic.gov.au/

urn:contentItem:64V9-8GW1-F0J6-J2NB-00000-00Mount Camel fire burns 150 hectares2022-02-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Mount Camel fire burns 150 hectares

Country Fire Authority crews took 90 minutes to contain a fire that burnt 150 hectares of land in the area near Davis Road in Mount Camel on Monday night.

The fire was originally sighted from a fire tower near Paddy Track, Mount Camel. On arrival, crews found a fire spreading quickly in a northerly direction.

About 30 CFA vehicles responded to the fire at 4.43pm including tankers and support vehicles, along with Forest Fire Management Victoria vehicles.

Five aircraft also assisted in controlling the fire.

It was brought under control at 6.15pm.

Crews remained on scene overnight to monitor the fire before leaving the scene at 7am on Tuesday.

A watch and act message was initially issued to the communities of Mount Camel, Ladys Pass, Redcastle and Moormbool West.

Once the fire was controlled, the message downgraded to an advice message.

urn:contentItem:647J-RNG1-JD3N-52H5-00000-00TRADITIONAL BURNING A GOAL FOR OTWAYS2021-12-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8TRADITIONAL BURNING A GOAL FOR OTWAYS

A PILOT training program will see members of the Wadawurrung community develop their fire management skills and share their knowledge of traditional burning with fire management specialists in the Otway District.

Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) and the Wadawurrung Traditional Owners Aboriginal Corporation co-designed the training, Twelve members of the Wadawurrung Corporation started the training course at Anglesea on Friday, building their capacity to use planned fire for cultural practices on public and private land. The training aims to merge the fire knowledge of Traditional Owners and FFMVic in a first step to reintroducing traditional burning into the Otway landscape.

urn:contentItem:64K5-BX11-JD3N-52DT-00000-00Holiday campfire warning2022-01-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Holiday campfire warningHannah Cohen

VICTORIANS planning to take a long weekend break are being urged to play it safe when it comes to campfires, barbecues and recreational fires.

Firefighters say campfires have led to 270 bushfires on public land this fire season, with at least 91 of these unattended campfires sparking bushfires over the Christmas and New Year period.

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman urged campers to never leave a campfire unattended and to use water, not soil, to completely extinguish the fire before leaving.

"Just one spark from an unattended campfire can have devastating impacts and get out of control," Mr Hardman said.

CFA chief officer Jason Heffernan reminded campers to be prepared before lighting a campfire by checking weather conditions and warnings, including total fire bans. Campers can find all this information on the Vic Emergency app or website.

urn:contentItem:60N1-WG61-F0J6-J4HF-00000-00Two men fined for firewood2020-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisTwo men fined for firewood

FOREST Fire Management Victoria has encouraged people to report illegal collection of firewood after two men were fined north of Maryborough. The men were each fined $661 for cutting and removing firewood from Timor State Forest. The activity took place outside of the firewood collection season on public land. "People can only take firewood from designated collection areas in state forests or parks during the autumn or spring firewood seasons," Forest Fire Management Victoria's Tim Wishart said.

urn:contentItem:64SX-JV11-F0JP-W53J-00000-00Restrictions to limit firewood for homes2022-02-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 17Restrictions to limit firewood for homesBy PETER HUNT

RESIDENTS of Melbourne, Geelong, Ararat, Ballarat, Bacchus Marsh and Benalla are among a long list of Victorians who will no longer be able to collect firewood from Central Victoria's state forests to warm their homes.

From March 1 domestic firewood collection will be restricted to residents of a select list of shires, which are all or partly within the Central zone.

Forest Fire Management Victoria planning team leader Amy Groch said the changes would help maintain a more sustainable domestic firewood supply.

"While firewood is free to collect, supply is not unlimited," Ms Groch said. "This means firewood needs to be managed responsibly to ensure environmental sustainability.

"These new restrictions have been introduced following extensive community consultation.

"We want to remind the community that firewood can only be taken from designated firewood collection areas in state forests during approved autumn and spring collection seasons, from March 1 to June 30 and from September 1 to November 30, respectively." FFMV has warned officers can ask people to prove their address and hefty penalties apply for breaching the rules.

urn:contentItem:63HR-YFT1-JD3N-54HN-00000-00Fire threatens species2021-09-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 12Fire threatens species

UNPRECEDENTED mapping of Amazon Basin habitats shows a majority of species threatened with -extinction suffered habitat loss due to fires over the past two decades, a study says. Researchers used remote forest fire sensing data to model impact over time and compared the devastation with the estimated geographic ranges of more than 11,500 plant and 3000 vertebrate species. The results showed about 150,000 square kilometres of the Amazon rainforest have experienced fires since 2001, damaging the habitats of up to 85 per cent of the frail ecosystem's threatened species.

urn:contentItem:63JP-9C71-F0J6-J4F0-00000-00Crews prepare for fire season2021-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisCrews prepare for fire seasonAlex Gretgrix

FOREST Fire Management Victoria crews will ramp-up targeted fuel management activities in coming months to reduce the risk of future bushfires in the Murray Goldfields district.

Planned burns are set for Bendigo, Castlemaine, Campbells Creek, Heathcote, Macedon, Avoca, Mount Hooghly, Rushworth and St Arnaud.

Slashing programs will begin around Echuca, Bendigo, Maldon, Castlemaine, Maryborough and St Arnaud on Crown land blocks and areas near built-up communities.

The strategic fuel management approach gives firefighters a better chance of controlling fires when they do occur - reducing impacts on people, property and the environment

Call the VicEmergency hotline on 1800 226 226 for more information.

Authorities hope to carry out a cultural planned burn north of Bendigo this weekend.

The Traditional Owner burn is planned for Tandarra - Thunder Swamp, near Dingee and will cover 57 hectares.

Forest Fire Management said smoke will be visible from the Tandarra, Kamarooka North, Kamarooka, Dingee, Yallook, Auchmore, Raywood and Drummartin districts.

Staff will patrol the burn until it is declared safe.

Firefighters will be better able to access incidents between Mitta and Mt Beauty with the replacement of two bridges.

The structures on Mountain Creek Road and Trappers Gap Road will be rebuilt in coming months to allow heavy firetrucks to cross.

Forest Fire Management spokesman Aaron Kennedy said the changes would allow safer and quicker access for firefighters and heavy machinery.

urn:contentItem:61F6-P1M1-F0J6-J426-00000-00Fuel reduction burn planned for Huntly2020-12-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisFuel reduction burn planned for Huntly

THERE will be a planned fuel reduction burn in Huntly on Friday.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the Country Fire Authority will carry out the burn at Viola Road, about 1.2 kilometres north east of Huntly, from 10am to midnight.

Authorities warned smoke from the 2.4 hectare burn could be visible to Huntly residents on Friday.

Read other news:

Company fined for dumping contaminated soil at Daylesford Works of 1960s fashion designer to feature at Bendigo Art Gallery Man denied bail in Bendigo Magistrates' Court after allegedly strangling woman Forest Fire Management advised people to close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering their homes.

Anyone experiencing symptoms due to smoke exposure should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

Road travel could also be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke. Signs may be in place to slow traffic.

More information about planned burns could be found at plannedburns.ffm.vic.gov.au/

urn:contentItem:62R1-J3X1-F0J6-J54B-00000-00Planned burn set for today2021-05-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Planned burn set for todayPeter Kennedy

Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA plan to burn more than 58 hectares of land near Torrumbarry from today.

The planned burn, weather conditions permitting, is set for a site in the Terrick Terrick National Park, about 12 kilometres south of Torrumbarry, and should be completed by 8pm, Saturday, May 22.

Residents are advised smoke may be visible in the Roslymead, Torrumbarry, Kotta, Wharparilla, Terrick Terrick East, Lockington, Mitiamo, Gunbower and Leitchville areas.

urn:contentItem:62PK-KTC1-JD34-V150-00000-00Baits set to target vermin2021-05-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Baits set to target vermin

An annual fox baiting program is under way across state forests in central Victoria aimed at reducing the impact foxes have on native wildlife, livestock and the environment.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Forest and Roading Officer Jeffrey Wilkie said foxes also carry disease and increase the spread of weeds by carrying seeds in their droppings and fur.

Baits have been laid in the Wareek State Forest, Bung Bong State Forest and Mount Hooghly State Forest.

FOREST Fire Management Victoria plans to light a 90-hectare burn on Bendigo's southern outskirts today. The burn will be lit two kilometres south west of Big Hill. urn:contentItem:62DV-8KX1-F0J6-J152-00000-00Reserve to shut for project2021-03-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Reserve to shut for project

Katie Peters Reserve at Eskdale will be closed for a week next month while North East Catchment Management Authority does habitat works along the adjacent section of the Mitta River.

Forest Fire Management Victoria will close the reserve to the public, including anglers and campers, between April 19 and 23.

The work is being done with the support of the Murray-Darling Basin Authority.

Campers and visitors are being asked to vacate the site on April 19 before 7.30am.

urn:contentItem:6263-X941-JD34-V33V-00000-00Works set to reduce fire risk2021-03-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Works set to reduce fire riskChris Pedler

Thirty locations across Bendigo will undergo fuel reduction works in the coming weeks. Forest Fire Management Victoria will use bulldozers, skid steers, slashing and clearing as part of the reduction works included in the Safer Together Bushfire Mitigation Plan. Among the locations are Junortoun, Kangaroo Flat, Myers Flat, Eaglehawk, Maiden Gully, Kangaroo Flat, Big Hill, Kennington and Strathfieldsaye.

The Safer Together program sees fire and land agencies work together to reduce bushfire risk.

The Department of Primary Industries' Information Centre Building on Natimuk Road had to be evacuated following the triggering of a smoke alarm.

The building was evacuated at 12.16pm, with emergency services resetting the alarm.

One tanker from the Horsham CFA brigade and one vehicle from Forest Fire Management were in attendance.

urn:contentItem:6341-7591-JD3N-519D-00000-00300 fireys needed for season2021-07-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6300 fireys needed for seasonMITCH CLARKE

UP to 300 new firefighting positions need to be filled across the state ahead of the upcoming bushfire season.

The state government has called on Victorians "from all walks of life" to apply to become a project firefighter with Forest Fire Management Victoria.

Successful recruits will undertake emergency response, conduct planned burns, manage roadside vegetation, maintain access to forest trails, and conduct pest and weed control.

Meanwhile, a number of Forest and Fire operations officer positions have also been made available.

Recruits would be required to carry out a range of land management activities including caring for our State Forests, recreation and tourism infrastructure and services.

The project firefighter roles include general firefighting duties, support officers and rappel crew. "Recent events have shown us just how critical these roles are in protecting Victorian communities and our precious wildlife," FFMVic chief fire officer Chris Hardman said.

urn:contentItem:5YGM-7761-F0J6-J17X-00000-00More Autumn burns planned2020-03-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4More Autumn burns plannedChris Pedler

IDEAL weather conditions including mild days, cool nights and light winds mean Forest Fire Management Victoria's planned burns will go ahead through autumn.

FFMVic has already conducted burns near Maryborough, Dunolly, St Arnaud, Castlemaine and, last weekend, in Heathcote.

Acting regional manager for forest fire operations Paul Bates said upcoming planned burns also included areas near One Tree Hill, Castlemaine, Denver, Macedon, Kyneton, Talbot, Wedderburn and Avoca.

"We have quite a few planned burns if conditions suit over next few weeks," he said.

"Sometimes people do ask why we do the bulk (of planned burns) in autumn. The stable and predictable weather conditions mean there will be light winds, mild days and cool nights.

"It is the best opportunity for for planned burns."

Mr Bates said FFMVic uses its strategic fire management plan to determine where it should conduct all of its planned burns.

urn:contentItem:5YN9-RY71-F0J6-J392-00000-00Planned burn to take place near Castlemaine2020-04-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:13ZLexisNexisPlanned burn to take place near Castlemaine

FOREST Fire Management and the Country Fire Authority will conduct a planned burn near Castlemaine from Tuesday.

The 34-hectare fuel reduction burn will take place at Castlemaine Kalimna Park, 500 metres east of Castlemaine, from 10am on Tuesday to 8pm on Wednesday.

Authorities advised Castlemaine, Barkers Creek, Chewton, and Campbells Creek residents may see smoke from the burn until Tuesday, April 21.

Read more: Dja Dja Wurrung, Forest Fire Management plan for more cultural burns in central Victoria in 2020

Authorities are advising some roads may be hazardous due to low viability associated with smoke. Signs may also be in place to slow traffic.

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites may also be restricted.

More information about planned burns can be found at plannedburns.ffm.vic.gov.au
